The traditional, deep red pigment of Swedish barns and cottages is called Falun Red (or Falu Röd.)  The paint originates from the Falun copper mines of Dalarma, Sweden and is composed of copper, zinc, and iron oxides mixed with rye flour, linseed oil, and water.  In use for nearly 500 years (and originally a symbol of wealth meant to emulate brick), the paint is renowned for its preservative qualities and can range in color from a light, chalky red to a deep black depending on preparation.
